description:
We live in a world inundated with media and saturated with images. What might be reported through television, documentary films, or magazines was once presented via illustrated texts and prints or else commemorated in public murals or statues. This course will follow the emergence of modern media - culminating in photography, film, and digital media - in an increasingly public and democratic sphere of art. Social changes in courts and cities, especially in the wake of the Industrial and French Revolutions, resulted from increasing capitalism and democracy. Artists had to adjust to new roles, media, and means of support. This course will introduce students from diverse backgrounds to visual media in culture and society, providing both critical and historical tools for visual literacy in the modern world. No Prerequisites. 

Taught regularly in spring term. It replaces the former ARTH 102 introductory course and satisfies History of Art 100-level course requirements. 

In consultation with the Undergraduate Chair, CGS students may be allowed to substitute CGS-taught ARTH 101 or 102 courses for the new ARTH 001 OR 002, respectively
name: RISE OF MOD VISUAL MEDIA: Renaissance to Contemporary

section.name: RISE OF MOD VISUAL MEDIA: Renaissance to Contemporary

values.comments:
This course studies great epochs of art and their relation to corresponding phases of Western political thought and sociological history. It is designed as both an introductory level course for an artistic student and as a course that provides a foundation for more specialized study in the field. 

Students felt that this course prepared them well for a future in the art world, and said that this course was a “great introduction to art history.” Many students commented on exciting and engaging lectures and discussions, and commented that they “enjoyed vising the art museum during recitation.” Since this course does cover a lot of historical ground, students were pleased by the amount of learning they had accomplished, but some students found the material to be too much so they felt “bogged down with reading.” One other student noted the some prior knowledge about art terminology and other historical movements that were not discussed fully in class. Another student noted that attendance is a very crucial aspect to the course, especially the recitations. 

Many students found Professor Poggi to be a “very knowledgable” professor who was “easy to follow,” and a “truly brilliant...expect in modern art.” Critiques of Professor Poggi dwelt on her often inability to give an overarching lesson or point to her lectures that made her slides seem disjointed. However, students were impressed by both Dombrowski and Poggi’s “dynamic lecturing styles” and one student went so far as to say that these were “among the best” professors at Penn. According to this student, both Professors are enthusiastic about their subject matter, and extremely knowledgeable. 

Although this is an introductory course directed towards tentative art history majors or at least those with an interest, many students found that the course covered more material than should be expected for an introductory level. Since the final is graded on accuracy down to the specific year, many students felt that the course required students “to memorize [an] inappropriately large” number of slides. Another student noted that “the papers required intense analysis” and others thought the material covered by the class was overwhelming, and cited a large number of assigned readings as major problem.
